div.p: Greetings. I was not intending to write, dear father; I was recently going to express my gratitude for all your many services.
But behold, yesterday evening it was said that someone had arrived from Milan, who reportedly said that all of Hannibal's forces had been destroyed, and Hannibal captured.
Today, letters come to Mr. Consul Ambrosius in Bellinzona from a reliable man, in which it is announced that those forces perished in a storm, and indeed entirely.

Now, what is true, we will hear shortly; I believe the matter is not without some credibility. He adds in his letters to the consul that the Genoese are in great danger, because indeed a man named St. Peter Corso has defected from them to the Turk and has taken a town in Corsica. This aligns with Mr. Beza's letters.
He further adds that the Genoese have sent certain men with orders to Milan to recruit new soldiers there; but the Milanese have been forbidden from military service under penalty of death.

However, the leaders and other commanders are said to have already been aware of the prohibition. I wanted to inform you of this suddenly and I doubt whether there is anyone to whom I can give letters; for I believe our people have already left.
On the first of August, in Chur, in the year 1564.
To the most esteemed Mr. Heinrich Bullinger, his most revered lord. In ZÃ¼rich.
